metadata.title: Effect of Zn doping on the hydrogenolysis of glycerol over ZnNiAl catalyst

Fig. 1 Schematic illustration for the formation of ZnNiAl catalysts. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the as-prepared precursors. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the calcined (a) and reduced (b) catalysts. Fig. 4 TEM and HRTEM images of the reduced catalysts: (a) and (b) NiAl; (c) and (d) ZnNiAl (1:5). Fig. 5 (a) The evolution of conversion of catalysts as a function of time. (b) The effect of Zn/Ni mole ratio on the selectivity of hydrogenolysis of glycerol at a constant conversion around 50%. Fig. 6 The evolution of selectivity and conversion over NiAl (a) and ZnNiAl (1:5) (b) as a function of time. Fig. 7 H2-TPR patterns (a) and H2-TPD patterns (b) of the catalysts. Fig. 8 The illustration of glycerol hydrogenolysis on the surface of NiAl and ZnNiAl. Effect of Zn doping on the hydrogenolysis of glycerol over ZnNiAl catalyst Xiaoru Li a b c Chao Zhang a b ⁎ Haiyang Cheng a b Limin He a b c Weiwei Lin a b c Yancun Yu a b Fengyu Zhao a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Electroanalytical Chemistry, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun 130022, PR China State Key Laboratory of Electroanalytical Chemistry, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Changchun 130022 PR China b Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Process, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun 130022, PR China Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Process, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Changchun 130022 PR China c University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: State Key Laboratory of Electroanalytical Chemistry, Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Process, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun 130022, PR China. Tel.: +86 431 85262410; fax: +86 431 85262410. Graphical abstract Nickel based catalyst is of interest in the industrial catalytic processes, and it is always modified by doping a second element to improve its catalytic properties. Understanding the role of dopant is extremely helpful in tailoring the active centers. In this work, Zn could induce a significant improvement of the catalytic performance of NiAl for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The Zn doped ZnNiAl catalysts exhibited high activity and the improved selectivity to 1,2-propanediol, it was about 2 times higher than the original ones. The ZnNi alloy formed in ZnNiAl was responsible for the noticeable catalytic performance. They preferred to coordinate with the end hydroxyl group of glycerol, promoted the cleavage of CO bond in glycerol, and resulted in the dominant formation of 1,2-propanediol. The findings described here will provide a useful knowledge for rational design of nickel-based catalysts, as well as reveal a new reaction model for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. Keywords ZnNiAl Glycerol hydrogenolysis Hydrotalcite precursors ZnNi alloy 1 Introduction Alloys and intermetallic compounds are of great interest as they often exhibit superior catalytic properties (including stability, activity and selectivity) to the corresponding single-metal component. Until now, the strategies such as composition, morphology and size controlling have been well developed in the preparation of alloy catalysts for achieving the outstanding catalytic performance [1–4]. However, the role of dopant is still not clear and leaves some challenges in designing high efficient bi-metallic catalysts. Rational selection of dopants can remarkably improve the performances of the catalysts [5,6]. In general, the introduction of a suitable dopant will result in a pronounced enhancement of activity [7,8], selectivity [9–12], and stability [13–15] due to the formation of defects (structure and electronic defects) [16–18], new active sites [19–21], acidic or basic sites [22,23]. Although there are some reports about the dopant-induced improvement of performances, detailed investigation on the nature of the dopant impact is still lacking. Therefore, the investigation at discovering the correlation between the dopant and the catalytic properties is still an important research issue. Understanding dopant-induced improvement of catalytic performance is particularly useful not only for revealing the catalytic mechanism, but also for the rational design of efficient catalysts. Nickel (Ni)-based catalyst, bearing excellent hydrogenation activities, has been widely explored and used in industrial catalytic processes [24–30]. Several methods have been reported for the preparation of highly efficient Ni catalysts via optimizing the composition, crystallite size, exposed facet and defect, and so on. Adding dopant is one of the most efficient methods for further improving the performance. Previous studies indicated that Zinc (as a structural promoter) can change the electronic properties of adjacent Ni atoms, resulting in an increase of selectivity and satisfactory stability in the hydrogenation of acetylene [17]. Can the strategy be applied for other hydrogenation reactions, what is the exact role of the Zinc, can the addition of the dopant change the reaction pathway? These are still unclear and remind a big challenge for the catalysis researchers. Biodiesels have attracted much attention worldwide as an important renewable energy source for the replacement of dwindling petroleum [31–33]. The increasing demand of biodiesels results in a large surplus of glycerol, a main byproduct of biodiesels production, consequently, the utilization of glycerol is crucial for improving the economy of the biodiesel production. Among the technologies for glycerol conversion, hydrogenolysis of glycerol to value-added chemicals, such as 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO), is one of the most promising processes due to the environmental friendly nature [32,34]. In this work, we study the hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO over Zn-doped NiAl catalysts, and mainly discuss the role of Zn. The ZnNi alloy was formed via Zn doping into Ni lattice, and it could change the electronic environment of adjacent Ni atoms, suppressed the activity of CC bonds cleavage, and then altered the hydrogenolysis pathway. The doping of Zn could greatly enhance both the reaction rate and selectivity to 1,2-PDO. It is expected that the findings about the correlation between dopant and performances described in this work will provide useful knowledge for the design of effective Ni-based hydrogenation catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The ZnNiAl hydrotalcite precursors were prepared by co-precipitation method. Required amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in distilled water and set the volume to 50ml. In order to maintain the hydrotalcite structure, the ratio of trivalent ions to divalent ion was kept at 0.25, and the total ion concentration of the metal salt solution is 1.0mol/L. Then metal salt solution was added to the base solution in which the concentration of Na2CO3 and NaOH are 0.8 and 1.2mol/L at the rate of 60ml per hour by a syringe pump. Afterward, the pH value was adjusted to 10 with 3mol/L NaOH aqueous solution. Then, the suspension was aged at 65°C for 22h. After that, the precipitate was washed with deionized water and dried at 80°C overnight; the catalysts were finally obtained by calcination of the precipitate in air at 500°C for 2h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction patterns of all involved catalysts were performed on Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer, using Cu-Kα radiation (λ =0.154nm). Prior to the test, samples were pre-reduced at 600°C for 2h. Crystallite sizes of Ni particles were determined by the most intense peaks at 2θ =44.5° (h k l =111) using the Scherrer equation, i.e. Dc= K λ/βcos θ, where the constant K here is 0.9, λ is the wavelength of the X-ray radiation, β is the width of the peak at half-maximum, and θ is the Bragg angle. Temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR), temperature-programmed desorption with H2 (H2-TPD), temperature-programmed desorption with NH3 (NH3-TPD) and temperature-programmed desorption with CO2 (CO2-TPD) were carried on the TP-5080 (Tianjin Xianquan Industry and Trade Development Co., Ltd, China), with a thermal conductivity detector. Before H2-TPR run, 30mg of the catalyst was loaded in the quartz tube and pretreated with ultra-pure nitrogen at 150°C for 10min. After cooling to room temperature, the sample cell was heated at a ramping rate of 10°C/min to 800°C in the atmosphere of H2/N2 mixture gas. The H2 uptake was quantified by the CuO as reference. For the H2-TPD test, 100mg of the sample was pre-reduced in pure H2 at 600°C for 1h. After the catalyst cooled to room temperature, desorption was carried out by heating the sample at a heating rate of 10°C/min to 850°C under N2 flow. For the NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD test, 100mg of the sample was pre-reduced in pure H2 at 600°C for 1h. After the catalyst cooled to room temperature, the adsorption was conducted by flushing the sample with pure NH3 or CO2 for 30min. Desorption was carried out at 850°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min under N2 flow for NH3-TPD and He flow for CO2-TPD. 2.3 Hydrogenolysis of glycerol The hydrogenolysis of glycerol was performed in a 50-mL stainless steel reactor with an inner Teflon coating. If no specific explanation, all the catalysts used in the reaction were pre-reduced in pure H2 at 600°C for 2h. The pre-reduced catalysts without exposing to air were added to autoclave containing 5ml 20% mass fraction glycerol and the autoclave was then flushed with H2 for more than three times and pressured to 3.0MPa, and then put in an oil bath coupled with a magnetic stirrer and thermoelectric couple. When the reactor was preheated to 230°C, the time counting began with the start of stirring. The agitation speed was 1200rpm, with it the mass and heat transfer limitations could be removed, which was verified before the reaction. After reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and vapor phase was collected by a gas-bag and analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, 14C) equipped with an active carbon column and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Liquid phase was centrifuged to remove the catalyst and analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, 14C) equipped with a capillary column (Restek Stabilwax 30m×0.53mm×1μm, carrier: N2) and a flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of the ZnNiAl catalysts Hydrotalcite-like compounds were proven to be excellent precursors for the preparation of highly dispersed metal catalysts due to their favorable layered structures [35–37]. Herein, a series of mono-dispersed ZnNiAl catalysts were synthesized through precipitation of Zn2+, Ni2+, and Al3+ ions with Na2CO3/NaOH and followed by thermal decomposition including calcination and reduction (see the schematic illustration in Fig. 1 ). Fig. 2 displays the XRD patterns of the formed precursors with and without Zn doping. The diffraction peaks can be easily indexed to the (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113) planes of the Zn-Ni-Al layered double hydroxides. As it can be seen from the XRD patterns, the addition of Zn (up to 1/5 of Ni content) had little influence on the structure except for a slight d-spacing's shift. After the heating treatment at 500°C for 2h, the NiAl precursors decomposed, and then formed rock salt phase NiO as shown in Fig. 3a. Noticeably, the diffraction peaks shifted to higher 2θ values relative to pure NiO (JCPDS: 65-2901), which indicated the existence of dissolved Al3+ ions in the NiO lattice [38–40]. Interestingly, the addition of the Zn2+ ions resulted in the return of the diffraction peaks gradually. This can be explained by the successful substitution of Ni2+ by Zn2+ due to their compatible radius and equal valance state [41]. The favorable layered double hydroxide (LDH) structure of the precursors and the pure NiO-type phase was helpful to improve the uniformity of the nuclei, thus formed highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles. The ZnNiAl catalysts prepared with different Zn contents are denoted as NiAl, ZnNiAl (1:14), ZnNiAl (1:10), and ZnNiAl (1:5) according to the controlled Zn/Ni mole ratios. The actual composition examined by ICP measurements matched well with the experimental controlled values (Zn:Ni ratios in Table S1). As shown in Fig. 3b, the as-synthesized catalysts showed broaden diffraction peaks at around 44.5, 51.8, and 76.6 degrees, which can be indexed to the (111), (100), and (200) planes of Ni (JCPDS: 04-0850), except for the slight shifts to lower angles. The purity of the phase together with the gradual shifts of the diffraction peaks upon the doping concentrations gave rise to a powerful evidence for the formation of ZnNi alloy. The Ni and/or ZnNi crystallite sizes calculated by Debye–Scherrer equation on (111) were around 5–6nm, which presented a little decrease with doping of Zn. Fig. 4 shows the typical TEM images for NiAl and ZnNiAl (1:5). As can be seen, the Ni nanoparticles for both samples are around 6nm with a narrow distribution, which is match well with the values calculated from the XRD results. The relative low doping concentration of Zn (Zn:Ni from 1:14 to 1:5) had little influence on the morphologies and sizes of the Ni nanoparticles. After a series of careful measurements (over 20 NPs), it was found that the average d-spacing of (111) planes were extended from the original 2.03nm (without Zn) to 2.06nm (Zn:Ni=1:5). The possible reason might be that the doped Zn caused lattice expansion in the alloys. TEM-EDS based elemental identifications are presented in Fig.S1. As observed from the line scanning results, the signal intensity of Ni and Zn (shown in the shadow) match well with the selected catalyst nanoparticle (marked with the red arrowhead), which identifies the formation of ZnNi alloy. 3.2 Catalytic performance of ZnNiAl catalysts As expected, the doping of Zn strongly affected the catalytic performances of NiAl. The evolution of conversion rate and product selectivity for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol as a function of time is given in Fig. 5 . Noticeably, the conversion was improved dramatically by doping of Zn, and it was only 18.0% over the NiAl catalyst after 2h of reaction, while it increased to about 50.0% with the Zn-doped catalysts as seen in Fig. 5a. However, the increasing of Zn content (from 1/14 to 1/5) had little influence on the conversion during the first 4h of reaction. Reaction conditions: 0.1g catalysts, 5ml 20wt% glycerol solution, 230°C, 3MPa H2. Other products include 1-propanol, 2-propanol, acetol, CO2 and CH4. In addition, the selectivity to 1,2-PDO and ethylene glycol (EG) was also modified remarkably. As shown in Fig. 5b, at a constant conversion of 50%, the selectivity to 1,2-PDO increased with doping of Zn, and it increased from 18.0% to 64.4% as Zn content (in mole ratio) increased from 0 to 1/5. At the same time the selectivity to EG decreased from 37.3% to 20.9%. For both NiAl and ZnNiAl (1:5) catalysts, 1,2-PDO and EG were main productions, and their selectivities dropped gradually with the prolonged reaction times as shown in Fig. 6 . For the NiAl catalyst, 1,2-PDO was produced with a selectivity of 20.1% and decreased to 14.6% with extending of reaction time. By contrast, for the ZnNiAl (1:5) catalyst, selectivity of 1,2-PDO reached as high as 64.4% and decreased slightly (54.2%) with extending of reaction time. Evidently, doping of Zn is effective to improve both the reaction rate and the product distribution for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. 3.3 Role of Zn dopant Here, H2-TPR and H2-TPD were examined for revealing the role of Zn based on the reduction and H2 surface adsorption behaviors. As presented in Fig. 7 , a broaden H2 consumption peak centered around 580°C was observed during the reduction process, which was assigned to the reduction of NiO. It is obvious that the reduction temperature shift slightly to the lower temperature, indicating the reducibility increased slightly with doping of Zn [41]. In addition, one predominant desorption peak presented between 100 and 200°C for all the catalysts, but it shifted to low temperature slightly and weakened with doping of Zn. The amount of hydrogen desorption calculated was 0.77, 0.69, 0.62, 0.60mmolg−1 (Ni) for NiAl, ZnNiAl (1:14), ZnNiAl (1:10), and ZnNiAl (1:5), respectively. The shift and decrease of the desorption peaks suggested that the strength of NiH bond was weakened and active Ni sites decreased along with increasing of Zn content. These strongly suggested that the doping of Zn has a significant effect on the electronic structure of metal active sites surface as well as the catalytic performance. Nozawa et al. revealed a dramatic change of the electronic structure caused by the formation of ZnNi alloy using First-principles slab calculations [42]. Besides, Nørskov et al. have also elucidated the change of electronic structure in ZnNi alloy through density functional theory and the experiment results of selective hydrogenation of acetylene [17]. In the hydrogenolysis of glycerol, two popular mechanisms were widely accepted for elucidating the formation of 1,2-PDO. Under acid conditions, acetol as a key intermediate was formed firstly from the direct intermolecular dehydration of glycerol and subsequent keto-enol tautomerization, then acetol was reduced to 1,2-PDO [43,44]. Under alkaline conditions, 1,2-PDO was formed via glyceraldehyde, through an initial dehydrogenation followed by water elimination through dehydroxylation by water or adsorbed hydroxyl and the final two reduction steps [45,46]. Qiao et al. reported that addition of ZnO to NiMo could improve the catalytic activity and selectivity because of the Lewis acid of ZnO [47,48]. Herein, CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD behaviors were also examined for all the catalysts used, and the results (Figs. S2 and S3) indicated that the Zn-doping did not cause much alteration in both acidic and basic characters of the catalysts. It seems neither of the above mechanisms are suitable to elucidate the enhanced conversion and selectivity to 1,2-PDO in this work. The present reaction was more likely to go along the first pathway due to the surface acidity of the catalyst. However, the reaction rate and product selectivity increased remarkably with Zn doping, even though the surface acidity did not change anymore. Therefore, some other factors or reaction mechanism should be considered (Fig. 8 ). Different from the acid mechanism, in which the hydrogenation of the intermediate, acetol, finished quickly under the reaction conditions (see Table S2), and the dehydration of glycerol to hydroxyacetone was the rate-determining step. The direct cleavage of CO bonds could take place over NiAl catalysts, which is also a popular mechanism for dehydroxylation of polyols, especially for hydroxyl elimination – hydrogenation process [33]. Controlled experiments were carried out to verify whether intramolecular dehydration was involved by addition of Al2O3, as acidic sites could promote glycerol hydrogenolysis as certified in Refs. [44,49]. However, the addition of Al2O3 did not show any improvement in the conversion and selectivity for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. Thus, it is concluded that the surface metal or alloy active sites rather than the acidic sites are the main effective factors to the CO bond cleavage in this system. Recently, Rajesh et al. also found that the above-mentioned two mechanisms were not always effective for explaining the experimental results in different reaction systems, and they used Langmiur–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson type reaction mechanism to explain the role of acid in glycerol hydrogenolysis over Cu-Zn-Cr-Zr mixed metal oxides catalyst. Besides, they also emphasized that the metal active sites were the most important part in the catalysis for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol [50]. Based on the above results and analysis, the role of doping Zn played in the improvements of activity and selectivity in hydrogenolysis of glycerol over ZnNiAl catalyst is concluded as follows. (1) As doping of Zn, Ni atoms could be substituted by Zn atoms, forming both the ZnNi alloy and the disordered Ni sites, increasing some new active sites which affected the activity and selectivity largely; (2) the ZnNi alloy formed on the surface of catalyst was favor to adsorb hydroxyl group of glycerol, weaken the CO bond due to the higher oxophilicity of Zn and so the direct cleavage of CO bonds became easily; (3) the activity for cleavage of CC bond over Ni active sites was suppressed greatly with doping of Zn. As mentioned above, the doping Zn could substitute Ni atoms near the surface or subsurface, resulting in some disordered Ni sites, as a result, the dehydrogenation and continuous cleavage of CC bond by decarbonylation over the metal sites was retarded, thus an improved selectivity to 1,2-PDO was obtained. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have demonstrated here that the Zn has a significant effect on the activity and selectivity of ZnNiAl catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The formation of ZnNi alloy contributes to the improvements of the catalytic performances. By doping of Zn, the arrangements of Ni atoms on the alloy surfaces are modified, which accelerates the cleavage of CO bond via a coordination of ZnNi alloy particles with the end hydroxyl group of glycerol, thus improves the selectivity to 1,2-PDO. Besides, a new glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction route is proposed for the ZnNiAl catalysts. This work not only reveals the nature of catalytic property alteration of ZnNiAl with Zn doping, but also provides valuable new insights into the mechanisms of glycerol hydrogenolysis. These findings may provide important reference for the rational design of Ni-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Nickel based catalyst is of interest in the industrial catalytic processes, and it is always modified by doping a second element to improve its catalytic properties. Understanding the role of dopant is extremely helpful in tailoring the active centers. In this work, Zn could induce a significant improvement of the catalytic performance of NiAl for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The Zn doped ZnNiAl catalysts exhibited high activity and the improved selectivity to 1,2-propanediol, it was about 2 times higher than the original ones. The ZnNi alloy formed in ZnNiAl was responsible for the noticeable catalytic performance. They preferred to coordinate with the end hydroxyl group of glycerol, promoted the cleavage of CO bond in glycerol, and resulted in the dominant formation of 1,2-propanediol. The findings described here will provide a useful knowledge for rational design of nickel-based catalysts, as well as reveal a new reaction model for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of Zn doping on the hydrogenolysis of glycerol over ZnNiAl catalyst
